node.text:
Hi, I'm Christine — host of “Christine vs. Work,” a series for our new brand, @HBRAscend.

In this episode, “How to Quit Your Job with No Regrets,” I tackle a topic that’s on a LOT of people’s minds during “The Great Resignation.” What should you consider before you decide to quit? What are the actual words you should use when you resign? Is there a right way — and a wrong way — to quit your job?

To help answer these questions, I talked to @dorieclark, who outlines a quitting game plan that will help you leave your company on the best possible terms. If quitting looks like the best decision for you, she explains how to break the news to your boss, what to say in the meeting, and how to think about your last days on the job.

I’m curious: What other work topics would you like me to look into next? I read every comment and would love to hear from you.

Don’t miss new Season 3 episodes of “Christine vs. Work.” Subscribe to the series on our YouTube channel, and check out more Ascend content @hbrascend

node.title: How to Quit Your Job with No Regrets

node.text:
What is it about communicating over Slack, email, and Zoom that seems to make conflict worse at work?

We invited Amy Gallo, a contributing editor at HBR and in-house conflict expert, on Instagram Live today to dive into the topic with HBR editor @ramsey.online.

Watch the video above for answers to questions like:

➡️ How can I work with a perfectionist teammate who micromanages?

➡️ How can I know if there’s conflict between my employees if they don’t mention it?

➡️ How can we build strong relationships remotely?

node.text:
People everywhere are thinking about quitting their jobs. But how do you decide if it's the right move for you? And if you do decide to quit, how do you give your notice and leave gracefully?

Editor Amy Gallo dug into the HBR archive to surface our best advice on quitting the right way — from figuring out how to tell your boss to how much notice to give. Learn more in the video above.

node.text:
It’s easy to feel demoralized when career progress is slow. Many of us are left wondering: Is my plan not working — or just not working yet?

Dorie Clark, a marketing strategist who has authored more than 200 HBR articles, argues that to build the career you want, you have to be willing to work the process. And it's often a long one.

HBR editor @ramsey.online spoke with @dorieclark on Instagram Live about how to know when to keep plugging along — and when it's time to move on.

You can watch the recording above ⬆️ and read more in the Clark's new article "Feeling Stuck or Stymied?" and her upcoming book "The Long Game."

node.text:
Hey! I’m Kelsey — host of “Career Crush,” a new series from @HBRAscend.

Organizations like the ACLU, and the amazing people who work for them, have been in the headlines more than ever as they continue to fight for things like free speech, LGBTQ+ rights, and police accountability.

I’m passionate about these causes. I can attend protests and sign petitions all day long, but in the end, it is the attorneys working in public interest law that will help to turn the changes I want to see into realities.

To learn more, I spoke with Jessica Lewis, a Staff Attorney for the American Civil Liberties Union of Massachusetts. Jessica shared with me the details about her career — from interning at the White House, to attending Harvard Law School, to working at the Southern Poverty Law Center, to becoming an attorney at the ACLU.

We also talked about the pay discrepancy between “big law” and public interest law, the pros and cons of following your passion, and what it really takes to change the world.

I’m really curious: Do you have a career crush? Let me know who they are in the comments (or tag your crush directly). I’d love to hear about them!

If you liked this episode, you can subscribe to the series on our YouTube channel, and check out more content @hbrascend! Thanks for watching.

node.title: What It’s Like to Be a Social Justice Lawyer

node.text:
Giving two-weeks’ notice is standard in the United States, where at-will employment reigns supreme. But what if there was a better way — for both workers and companies?

@robertglazer_, CEO and founder of the global marketing agency Acceleration Partners, champions a culture where safe, open conversations about career trajectories between employees and managers are commonplace — and where employees feel comfortable speaking up when it's time for them to start looking for their next opportunity.

HBR associate editor @ramsey.online spoke with Robert on Instagram Live about how his company's transition program eliminates the element of surprise when an employee is moving on. Watch the video above, and read more about the topic in his article on HBR.org:

"The ‘Two Weeks’ Notice’ Approach to Changing Jobs Is Bad for Companies and Employees”

node.text:
Hey! I’m Kelsey — host of “Career Crush,” a new series from @HBRAscend.

I am fascinated by coding. It's everywhere! Every single one of the digital experiences we enjoy is the result of code. But honestly, I know almost nothing about how it works or how the people behind the code — software engineers — do what they do.

To find out, I spoke with Lindsey Redd.

Lindsey has coded for some of the coolest tech companies in the world: Slack, Lyft, and now Stripe. She shared with me the details of her journey — from wanting to be a doctor, to studying computer science at Stanford, to thriving in the top echelons of software engineering. We also talked about some common misconceptions about software engineers, what it’s like to work in a predominately white and male industry, and how to nail an interview for a job like hers.

I’m really curious: Do you have a career crush? Let me know who they are in the comments (or tag your crush directly). I’d love to hear about them!

If you liked this episode, you can subscribe to the series on our YouTube channel, and check out more content @hbrascend!

node.title: What Is It Like to Be a Software Engineer? | Career Crush

node.text:
Yesterday on Instagram Live, HBR editor @ramsey.online spoke with @lilyzheng308, a diversity, equity, and inclusion strategist. He asked: What does it mean to be an ally, advocate, and activist today — especially as more and more companies are focused on DE&I? And how can each of us help serve those who are underrepresented? See our video above to watch the discussion.

Articles by Lily Zheng on HBR.org:

"It's Not Your Coworkers' Job to Teach You About Social Issues"

"How to Show White Men That Diversity and Inclusion Efforts Need Them"

"Adapt Your D&I Efforts to the Reality of the Crisis"

"We're Entering the Age of Corporate Social Justice"

"Do Your Employees Feel Safe Reporting Abuse and Discrimination?"

"Transgender, Gender-Fluid, Nonbinary, and Gender-Nonconforming Employees Deserve Better Policies"

"To Dismantle Anti-Asian Racism, We Must Understand Its Roots"

"Your Rainbow Logo Doesn't Make You an Ally"

node.text:
Hey! I’m Kelsey — host of “Career Crush,” a new series from @HBRAscend.
What’s a career crush? It’s a platonic crush you develop on someone who has a really cool job and is doing really cool things. In this episode, I interviewed one of my career crushes, Dave Jorgenson (@dave.jorgenson), to get to the bottom of what it’s like to be a full-time TikTok producer.

Dave's entire job is to make TikToks for the @washingtonpost. And his videos hit the mark — they're consistently informative, funny, and on-trend. I've always wondered: How does he do it? How does he continue to make hilarious, news-centered videos every day? What is it like to make TikToks for a living?

I sat down with Dave to chat with him about his journey from interning at The Colbert Report, to making YouTube videos, to becoming the newspaper-hat-wearing TikToker. We discussed his creative process, how he turned his job into one he loves, and how he helped The Washington Post’s TikTok reach almost one million followers.

I’m also really curious: Do you have a career crush? Let me know who they are in the comments (or tag your crush directly). I’d love to hear about them!

If you liked this episode, you can subscribe to the series on our YouTube channel, and check out more content @hbrascend! Thanks for watching 🤗

node.title: What It’s Like to Make TikToks for a Living

node.text:
Women are often told that if they can fix their imposter syndrome, they'd be more successful in their careers. But is it really a lack of confidence holding them back — or is it systemic bias?

Today we spoke with @jodiannburey and @rtulshyan, HBR authors working to debunk the idea that imposter syndrome is a problem that's on individuals to solve. They argue that the “diagnosis” of imposter syndrome is problematic because it fails to acknowledge the historical and cultural contexts that affect the way women are treated — especially women of color.

Watch the full live conversation with HBR editor @ramsey.online here and add any questions you have about the topic in the comments.

Find the articles on HBR.org:

"Stop Telling Women They Have Imposter Syndrome"

"End Imposter Syndrome in Your Workplace"

node.text:
Hi, I'm Christine — host of “Christine vs. Work,” a series for our new brand @HBRAscend.

In this episode, “How to Get Out of a Creative Rut,” I come face-to-face with my biggest demon: feeling mentally blocked. Some days I feel extremely inspired and productive; then there are others when I’m convinced I have no more ideas left in my brain. Nada. Nothing. Nope.

To help, I confessed my anxieties to entrepreneur @sonjarasula, who reassured me that creative ruts happen to everyone and they are completely normal (and expected). She offered ideas on how to reset ourselves to escape the typical creative rut, and strategies to prevent a bigger creative crisis down the line.
I’m curious: What other work topics would you like me to tackle next? I read every comment and would love to hear from you.

Don’t miss new Season 2 episodes of “Christine vs. Work.” Subscribe to the series on our YouTube channel, and check out more Ascend content @HBRAscend.

node.title: How to Get Out of a Creative Rut

node.text:
👋 Hi, I'm Christine — host of “Christine vs. Work,” a series for our new brand @HBRAscend.

There are plenty of challenges when it comes to trusting colleagues, especially in a world with hybrid offices and remote teams. Do people trust me? How can I make sure there’s trust on my team? And what can I do if trust is broken?

In this episode, “How to Build — and Repair — Trust at Work,” @LSU_slhrd professor Tyree Mitchell and I explore the building blocks of trust, how to embed it in a work culture, and what to do when it breaks down.

I’m curious: What other work topics would you like me to tackle next? I read every comment and would love to hear from you.

Don’t miss new Season 2 episodes of “Christine vs. Work.” Subscribe to the series on our YouTube channel, and check out more Ascend content @HBRAscend. ✌️

node.title: How to Build — and Repair — Trust at Work

They tend to achieve more than those with a more fixed mindset (those who believe their talents are innate gifts)." Read the full article, "What Having Actually Means," by Carol Dweck Growth Mindset''.

node.text:
What is a "growth mindset," really? To understand what the buzzy phrase actually means, first we have to understand the big misconceptions around it.

At the link in our bio, Carol Dweck deconstructs a few common myths about what it means to have a growth mindset.

Adapted from "What Having a 'Growth Mindset' Actually Means," by Carol Dweck.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Harvard Business Review on September 16, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Should Your Company Implement a Vaccination Mandate? Seven steps to help you decide.'.

node.text:
The recent and rapid spread of the Delta variant has forced companies that haven’t already mandated vaccinations to consider doing so. Those still deliberating their options should realize that their decision could have a significant impact on their short-term productivity and profits — as well on their long-term ability to attract and retain needed talent.

Visit the article for seven steps to figure out if a vaccination mandate is right for your company.

Adapted from "Should Your Company Implement a Vaccination Mandate?" by Jeff Levin-Scherz and Mike Orszag. Artist credit: master1305/Getty Images.

Photo by Harvard Business Review on September 15, 2021. May be an image of text that says '90% of business leaders cite data literacy as key to company success but only 25% of workers feel confident in their data skills. Adapted from "How Data Literate Is Your Company?" by Rasheed Sabar HBR'.

node.text:
As companies increasingly rely on data and analytics, leaders are putting a premium on a particular skill: data literacy.

But evidence suggests that most companies are still struggling to build this skill into their workforce, and only a quarter of employees report feeling confident in their data skills.

Tap the link in our bio for five strategies that can help your company expand its data literacy.

Adapted from "How Data Literate Is Your Company?" by Rasheed Sabar

node.text:
Hi, I'm Christine — host of “Christine vs. Work,” a series for our new brand, @HBRAscend.

In this episode, “How to Quit Your Job with No Regrets,” I tackle a topic that’s on a LOT of people’s minds during “The Great Resignation.” What should you consider before you decide to quit? What are the actual words you should use when you resign? Is there a right way — and a wrong way — to quit your job?

To help answer these questions, I talked to @dorieclark, who outlines a quitting game plan that will help you leave your company on the best possible terms. If quitting looks like the best decision for you, she explains how to break the news to your boss, what to say in the meeting, and how to think about your last days on the job.

I’m curious: What other work topics would you like me to look into next? I read every comment and would love to hear from you.

Don’t miss new Season 3 episodes of “Christine vs. Work.” Subscribe to the series on our YouTube channel, and check out more Ascend content @hbrascend

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Harvard Business Review on September 13, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Let's Redefine "Productivity" for the Hybrid Era It's time to expand the definition to include well-being, social connection, and collaboration.'.

node.text:
When companies first went remote, many were surprised to see that their standard metrics of productivity remained high. It may be tempting to equate these high levels with success, but doing so misses the factors that drive long-term, sustainable innovation.

Here are three crucial components to keep in mind in the hybrid era:

1️⃣ Consider well-being. Different types of boundaries work for different people — and getting it right can mean better quality work. Ask people to reflect on things such as whether they work best in the morning or evening, or whether they work better from a certain location.

2️⃣ Consider collaboration. Set team norms to determine when your team will convene in person — and certain hours of the week that must be protected from meetings.

3️⃣ Consider innovation. Think about the conditions that can foster it. If working together in person is where that happens, figure out which parts of each project would benefit most from going into the office — and which parts might best be completed remotely.

Tap the link in our bio to read the full article.

Adapted from "Let’s Redefine 'Productivity' for the Hybrid Era" by Jaime Teevan. Art credit: Yaroslav Danylchenko/Stocksy.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Harvard Business Review on September 12, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'HBR PSYCHOLOGY How do we go about getting our joy back at work? Research tells us that it comes from taking advantage of our strengths, as well as being courageous, authentic, grateful, and connected. Read the full article, "Rediscover Joy at Work," by Rebecca Newton'.

node.text:
When was the last time you felt joy at work? For many of us, it's been a while.

To bring back joy into your professional life, it helps to understand why it has disappeared. The obvious answer might be “the pandemic,” but it’s worth taking a closer look at what's specifically amiss.

Tap the link in our bio to read about four common reasons why you might be feeling an acute absence of joy at work these days — and four strategies to rediscover it.

Adapted from "Rediscover Joy at Work," by Rebecca Newton.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Harvard Business Review on September 09, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Boards Need Real Diversity, Not Tokenism Companies that wish to uphold a genuine commitment to DE&I must consider how and why their actions fall short of their intentions. D00'.

node.text:
After nearly a year of review, the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission has approved a proposal from Nasdaq to enhance diversity and inclusion in company board rooms. The U.S.-based stock exchange will now require all listed companies to disclose board-level diversity using a standard template, and to have at least two directors from underrepresented groups, “including one who self-identifies as female and one who self-identifies as either an underrepresented minority or LGBTQ+” — or explain why they do not.

In light of these new requirements, how can companies create and enable high-functioning, representative boards?

☑️ Evolve views of diversity to go beyond tokenism. Diversity’s true force is the unique and varied expertise and experiences that, when integrated, drive problem-solving, improve decision-making, and expand creative potential.

☑️ Access board candidates with a wider variety of identities and experiences by expanding beyond existing networks.

☑️ Cultivate genuine commitment by defining a purpose.

Tap the link in our bio to learn more.

Adapted from "Boards Need Real Diversity, Not Tokenism," by Simran Jeet Singh.

node.text:
What is it about communicating over Slack, email, and Zoom that seems to make conflict worse at work?

We invited Amy Gallo, a contributing editor at HBR and in-house conflict expert, on Instagram Live today to dive into the topic with HBR editor @ramsey.online.

Watch the video above for answers to questions like:

➡️ How can I work with a perfectionist teammate who micromanages?

➡️ How can I know if there’s conflict between my employees if they don’t mention it?

➡️ How can we build strong relationships remotely?

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Harvard Business Review on September 07, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'HBR TIME OFF Is Your Motivation Still on Vacation? There are many reasons why you might be having hard time getting work done after your vacation. Before you can take steps to energize yourself, you need to understand a little more about why you re having trouble getting started.'.

node.text:
Are you struggling to get back into a groove post-vacation? Here are three common reasons why you might be lagging — and what to do about them.

1. If you’re feeling overwhelmed, turn abstract tasks into specific steps you can complete.

2. If your work doesn’t feel important, look at the work you’ve done over the past few months and catalog what it has added up to.

3. If you’re just feeling bored with your work, take steps to advance your career, either at your company or a new one.

Tap the link in our bio to read the full article.

Adapted from "Is Your Motivation Still on Vacation?" by Art Markman

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Harvard Business Review on September 06, 2021. May be an image of text that says '* 8 Ways Managers Can Support Employees' Mental Health'.

node.text:
Uncertainty breeds anxiety — and we are living through deeply uncertain times. Between rising numbers of Covid-19 cases, questions about whether or not to reopen economies and businesses, the economic fallout of the pandemic, climate change, and a host of ongoing social and political issues, we don’t know what will come next. And that’s taking a toll on our mental health, which, in turn, affects our performance at work.

Managers have a key role to play in supporting their employees' mental health. Swipe for eight strategies and tap the link in our bio to read the full article.

"8 Ways Managers Can Support Employees’ Mental Health," by Kelly Greenwood and Natasha Krol. Artist credit: Illustration by Marco Vannini

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Harvard Business Review on September 06, 2021. May be an image of text that says '* 8 Ways Managers Can Support Employees' Mental Health'.

Photo by Harvard Business Review on September 06, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Nearly 42% of employees report a decline in mental health since the pandemic began, according to recent research. What can managers do to help? Swipe for eight tips.'.

Photo by Harvard Business Review on September 06, 2021. May be an image of text that says '1 Be vulnerable. Being honest about your mental health struggles as a leader opens the door for employees to feel comfortable talking with you about mental health challenges of their own.'.

Photo by Harvard Business Review on September 06, 2021. May be an image of text that says '2 Model healthy behaviors. Share that you're taking a walk in the middle of the day, having a therapy appointment, or prioritizing a staycation (and actually turning off email) so that you don't burn out.'.

Photo by Harvard Business Review on September 06, 2021. May be an image of text that says '3 Build a culture of connection through check-ins. Intentionally checking in with each of your direct reports on a regular basis is more critical than ever. Go beyond a simple "How are you?" and ask specific questions about what supports would be helpful.'.

Photo by Harvard Business Review on September 06, 2021. May be an image of text that says '4 Be flexible and inclusive. Expect that the situation, your team's needs, and your own needs will continue to change. Take a customized approach to addressing stressors, such as challenges with childcare, eldercare, and remote work expectations.'.

Photo by Harvard Business Review on September 06, 2021. May be an image of text that says '5 Communicate more than you think you need to. Make sure you keep your team informed about any organizational policies, and set expectations about priorities and accountability.'.

Photo by Harvard Business Review on September 06, 2021. May be an image of text that says '6 Invest in training. Prioritize proactive and preventive workplace mental health training for leaders, managers, and individual contributors. If you don't have the budget to invest in training, mental health employee resource groups are a low-cost way to increase awareness, build community, and offer peer support.'.

Photo by Harvard Business Review on September 06, 2021. May be an image of text that says '7 Modify policies and practices. Be as generous and flexible as possible in updating policies and practices around flexible hours, paid time off, email and other communications, and paid and unpaid leave reaction to the pandemic and civil unrest.'.

Photo by Harvard Business Review on September 06, 2021. May be an image of text that says '8 Track progress over time. Ensuring accountability doesn't have to be complicated; it can be handled in a simple pulse survey done regularly to understand how people are doing now and over time.'.

Photo by Harvard Business Review on September 02, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'McKinsey estimates a $220 billion annual wage disparity between Black and white Americans. Black workers are disproportionately represented in low-wage jobs, underrepresented in high-wage jobs, and are paid less, on average, than white workers in the same roles. Adapted from "Closing the Job Mobility Gap Between Black and White Americans," by Shelley Stewart III et al.'.

node.text:
New research from McKinsey finds critical gaps that Black Americans face not only as workers, but also as business owners, savers and investors, consumers, and residents that prevent full participation in the U.S. economy and significantly limit economic mobility.

While these gaps are substantial, the research suggests ways to close them.

Two initiatives, in particular, could make a big difference: unblocking pipelines into higher-paying professions and creating new career pathways from lower-paying occupations.

Tap the link in our bio to read more.

Adapted from "Closing the Job Mobility Gap Between Black and White Americans," by Shelley Stewart III et al.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Harvard Business Review on September 01, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'HBR STRATEGY "Traditional corporate social responsibility and philanthropy are inadequate for our times. Leaders must rethink what a business is and how it drives change in the world." Read the full article, "The Net Positive Manifesto," by Paul Polman and Andrew Winston'.

node.text:
"Companies that have embraced action on environmental, social, and governance issues are outpacing their competitors," write consultant and author Andrew Winston and former Unilever CEO Paul Polman. "Businesses that thrive in this new environment will look different from those of the past."

Tap the link in our bio to read Polman and Winston's vision of a "net positive" company.

Adapted from "The Net Positive Manifesto," by Paul Polman and Andrew Winston. Artist credit: Guillaume Kurkdjian.
